verses.text: The word of the LORD of hosts came to me, saying:
verses.comment: Throughout Zechariah, 'LORD of hosts' emphasizes God's sovereign power. This phrase is deeply rooted in Hebrew Scripture as a declaration of God’s authority over all armies—earthly and heavenly.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD of hosts: 'I am exceedingly jealous for Zion; yes, with great wrath I am jealous for her.'
verses.comment: God’s jealousy here signifies His passionate love and covenant faithfulness to His people, as seen repeatedly in Israel’s history. Zion comes to represent both the earthly city and the spiritual community.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD: 'I will return to Zion and will dwell in the midst of Jerusalem. Jerusalem will be called the City of Truth, and the mountain of the LORD of hosts the Holy Mountain.'
verses.comment: God promising to dwell in Jerusalem foreshadows His real presence among His people, fulfilled spiritually in Christ and in the worshiping assembly. The city becomes holy due to God’s dwelling.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD of hosts: 'Old men and old women will again sit in the streets of Jerusalem, each with their staff in hand because of great age.'
verses.comment: The restoration is complete—peace and security allow even the elderly to thrive, symbolizing life and future hope in God’s renewed city.

verses.text: And the streets of the city will be full of boys and girls playing.
verses.comment: Youthful joy fills Jerusalem; this marks a dramatic reversal of exile and suffering, indicating the fullness of community life and God’s blessing.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD of hosts: 'If it seems marvelous in the eyes of the remnant of this people in these days, should it also seem marvelous in My eyes?' declares the LORD of hosts.
verses.comment: 'Marvelous' shows how great God’s works are; even what seems impossible for humans is never too hard for God.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD of hosts: 'Behold, I will save My people from the land of the east and from the land of the west.'
verses.comment: A promise of gathering God’s scattered people, a theme later applied spiritually to all nations in the New Covenant (see Gal. 3:28).

verses.text: I will bring them back and they will dwell in the midst of Jerusalem. They will be My people, and I will be their God, in truth and in righteousness.
verses.comment: Restoration includes a renewed relationship—echoing covenant language fulfilled in Christ’s body, the Church. God’s righteousness permeates the community.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD of hosts: 'Let your hands be strong, you who now hear these words that were spoken by the prophets when the foundation was laid for the house of the LORD of hosts, that the temple might be built.'
verses.comment: God commands perseverance in rebuilding the Temple—highlighting the importance of sacred space and worship. This points ahead to worship in Spirit and truth.

verses.text: 'For before these days there was no wage for man or beast; there was no safety from adversary for those who went out or came in, for I set every man against his neighbor.'
verses.comment: 'No wage' and 'no safety' refer to the hardship of pre-restoration days, showing the impact of disobedience and exile.

verses.text: 'But now I will not deal with the remnant of this people as in the former days,' says the LORD of hosts.
verses.comment: God’s mercy inaugurates a new era, similar to the New Testament theme of grace after judgment.

verses.text: 'For there will be peace for the seed; the vine will produce its fruit, the ground will yield its increase, and the heavens will give their dew. I will cause the remnant of this people to inherit all these things.'
verses.comment: Blessings of restoration echo the prosperity promised for covenant obedience, connecting to the theme of spiritual fruitfulness (John 15:5).

verses.text: 'As you have been a curse among the nations, O house of Judah and house of Israel, so I will save you, and you shall be a blessing. Do not fear—let your hands be strong!'
verses.comment: Israel is transformed from cursed to blessed, an anticipation of God's universal salvation plan. Note the reversal of fortunes through divine initiative.

verses.text: For thus says the LORD of hosts: 'Just as I purposed to bring disaster on you when your ancestors provoked Me to wrath,' says the LORD of hosts, 'and I did not relent,
verses.comment: God’s justice in the exile reveals His faithfulness and consistency in upholding His covenant.

verses.text: 'so again I have purposed in these days to do good to Jerusalem and to the house of Judah. Do not be afraid.'
verses.comment: The promise to 'do good' reconnects God’s action to His ultimate plan of redemption—fulfilled in spiritual restoration through Christ.

verses.text: 'These are the things you shall do: Speak truth to one another; judge with truth and justice in your gates.'
verses.comment: Ethical commands shape God’s people; truth and justice are foundational both for the nation and the Church’s mission.

verses.text: 'Do not plot evil in your hearts against one another; do not love false oath, for all these are things that I hate,' declares the LORD.
verses.comment: Internal purity matters—God despises deceit. Spiritual renewal involves the heart, as Jesus expands upon in His ministry.

verses.text: The word of the LORD of hosts came to me, saying:
verses.comment: A new message signals a transition, marking hope and change in prophetic announcements.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD of hosts: 'The fasts of the fourth, fifth, seventh, and tenth months will become joy and gladness and cheerful festivals for the house of Judah; therefore love truth and peace.'
verses.comment: Fasts commemorating past tragedies are transformed into celebrations—a sign that God’s salvation reinterprets rites, echoing the move from old to new covenant worship.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD of hosts: 'Peoples shall yet come, and inhabitants of many cities;
verses.comment: The prophet foresees the nations coming to worship the Lord—a foretaste of universal worship, further fulfilled in the New Testament assembly.

verses.text: The inhabitants of one city will go to another, saying, 'Let us go at once to seek the LORD of hosts and to plead for His favor.' 'I too will go.'
verses.comment: Zeal for the Lord brings collective pilgrimage—a model for seeking God in community. Unity in worship hints at one visible faith community.

verses.text: Many peoples and strong nations will come to seek the LORD of hosts in Jerusalem and to plead for the LORD’s favor.
verses.comment: Universal pilgrimage anticipates salvation being offered to all nations, reinforcing the centrality of Jerusalem and worship in God’s plan.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD of hosts: 'In those days ten men from every language of the nations will take hold of the cloak of a Jew, saying,
'Thus says the LORD of hosts: In those days ten men from all languages and nations will grasp the cloak of one Jew, saying,
Thus says the LORD of hosts: 'In those days ten men from all languages of the nations will take hold of the hem of a Jew’s robe, saying,
